{"comments": {"id": 545, "count": 237, "talk_id": 664}, "threadId": 545, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "664", "description": "Reuse of syringes, all too common in under-funded clinics, kills 1.3 million each year. Marc Koska clues us in to this devastating global problem with facts, photos and hidden-camera footage. He shares his solution: a low-cost syringe that can't be used twice.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2009", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Marc Koska: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe", "slug": "marc_koska_the_devastating_toll_of_syringe_reuse", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "570", "slug": "marc_koska", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Marc", "lastname": "Koska", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Inventor", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/124721_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "As a member of Parliament with an interest in HIV and AIDS, to learn of Marc's work with Star Syringe was an inspiration. He will always be one of my heroes!", "whotheyare": "Marc Koska wants to improve health care in the developing world by re-designing dangerous medical tools -- and offering education to practitioners in under-funded clinics.", "whylisten": "

In 1984, Marc Koska read an article that predicted HIV would spread widely through unsafe injections. He writes, "Appalled at the prospect of such an avoidable catastrophe, I decided there and then to try and do something about it." The prediction, sadly, turned out to be true: syringe reuse now accounts for 1.3 million deaths -- more than malaria. In the next years, Koska undertook the study of public health to find out what could be done. He determined that the design of syringes was the critical issue.

Today, Koska's solution to the problem, the K1 syringe -- it locks down after a single injection, preventing reuse -- is in use by millions. But he hasn't stopped there: In 2005, he founded a nonprofit, SafePoint, which aims to educate people in the developing world about the dangers of reusing any instruments that come into contact with blood.

"is_published": true, "firstname": "Marc", "lastname": "Koska", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Inventor", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/124721_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "As a member of Parliament with an interest in HIV and AIDS, to learn of Marc's work with Star Syringe was an inspiration. He will always be one of my heroes!", "whotheyare": "Marc Koska wants to improve health care in the developing world by re-designing dangerous medical tools -- and offering education to practitioners in under-funded clinics.", "whylisten": "

In 1984, Marc Koska read an article that predicted HIV would spread widely through unsafe injections. He writes, "Appalled at the prospect of such an avoidable catastrophe, I decided there and then to try and do something about it." The prediction, sadly, turned out to be true: syringe reuse now accounts for 1.3 million deaths -- more than malaria. In the next years, Koska undertook the study of public health to find out what could be done. He determined that the design of syringes was the critical issue.

Today, Koska's solution to the problem, the K1 syringe -- it locks down after a single injection, preventing reuse -- is in use by millions. But he hasn't stopped there: In 2005, he founded a nonprofit, SafePoint, which aims to educate people in the developing world about the dangers of reusing any instruments that come into contact with blood.

"}], "speaker_name": "Marc Koska", "tags": ["design", "health", "medicine", "sanitation", "science", "technology", "global development", "Vaccines", "biotech"], "title": "1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 664456}]}
author: Marc_Koska;
title: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe

aws-transcripts.transcript: 25 a quarter years ago, I read a newspaper article which said that one day syringes would be one of the major causes of the spread of AIDS, the transmission of AIDS. I thought this was unacceptable, so I decided to do something about it. Sadly, it's come true. Malaria is, we all know, kills approximately 1,000,000 people a year. The re use of syringes now exceeds that and kills one point 3,000,000 people a year. This young girl on her friend that I met in an orphanage in Delhi were HIV positive from a syringe on what was so sad about this particular story was that that once their parents had found out and don't forget, their parents took them to the doctor. The parents threw them out on the street, and hence they ended up in an orphanage. And it comes from situations like this where you have either skilled or unskilled practitioners blindly. Giving an injection to someone on the injection is so valuable that the people basically trust the doctor being second to God, which I've heard many times to do the right thing. But in fact they're not, and you can understand, obviously the transmission problem between people in high virus areas. This video we took undercover, which shows you over half an hour period a tray of medicines of 42 vials, which were being delivered with only two syringes in a public hospital in India. And over the course of half on hour, not one syringe was filmed being unwrapped. They started we, too, and they ended with two and you'll see just now a nurse coming back to the tray, which is there sort of modular station on dropping the syringe. She's just used back in the trade for it to be picked up used again, so you can imagine the scale of this problem. And in fact, in India or alone, 62% of all injections given are unsafe. These kids in Pakistan don't go to school. They're lucky they already have a job, and that job is that they go around and pick up syringes from the back of hospitals, wash them on DDE. In the course of this, obviously picking them up, they injure themselves on. Then they repackage them and sell them out on markets for literally more money than a sterile syringe. in the first place, which is quite bizarre on an interesting photo that their father, while we were talking to him, picked up a syringe and pricked his finger identity. You can see the drop of blood on the end on Dhe immediately whipped out a box of matches lit one on burnt the blood off the end of his finger, giving me full assurance that that was the way that you stopped the transmission of HIV. In China, recycling is a major issue on their collected on mass. You can see the scale of it here on, sorted out by hand, back into the right sizes on dhe, then put back out on the street. So recycling and re use are the major issues here. But there was one interesting anecdote that I found in Indonesia. In all schools in Indonesia, there's usually a toy seller in the playground. The toy seller in this case had syringes, which they usually do next door to the diggers, which is obviously what you would expect, and they used them in the brakes for water pistols. They squirt them in each other, which is lovely and innocent, and they're having great fun but they also drink from them while they're in there. Breaks because it's hot and they squirt the water into their mouths. On. These are used with blood traces of blood in the visible, so we need a better product on. We need better information. And I think if I could just borrow this camera, I was going to show you my invention, which I came up with to do so. It's a normal looking syringe you loaded up in the normal way. This is made on existing equipment, 14 factories that be licensed. You give the injection and then put it down. If someone then tries to reuse it, it locks and breaks afterwards. It's very, very simple. On it costs the same as a normal syringe, and in comparison, a Coca Cola is 10 times the price, and that will stop reusing a syringe 20 or 30 times on. Then I have information charity, which has done a huge scale amount of work in India on we're very proud of giving information to people so that little kids like this Don't be stupid things. Thank you
